content: Malaysian and Singaporean traditional dish **Ayam masak merah** ([Jawi](/wiki/Jawi_script): ‏ايم ماسق ميره‎; lit. 'red-cooked chicken' in [Malay](/wiki/Malay_language); Malay pronunciation: [ˌajam ˌmasaʔ ˈmerah]) is a [Malaysian](/wiki/Malaysian_cuisine) and [Singaporean](/wiki/Singaporean_cuisine) chicken dish. Popular in both countries, it is a casserole of chicken pieces in dried chillies sambal. It tends to be a home-cooked dish, so many variations on the recipe exist. Pieces of chicken are first [marinated](/wiki/Marinated) in [turmeric](/wiki/Turmeric) before being [fried](/wiki/Frying) to a golden brown then slowly [braised](/wiki/Braised) in a spicy dried [chillies](/wiki/Chilli_pepper), [onion](/wiki/Onion) and [tomato sauce](/wiki/Tomato_sauce). [Peas](/wiki/Peas) are sometimes added to the dish, as are aromatic spices such as [cloves](/wiki/Cloves), [star anise](/wiki/Star_anise) and [cinnamon](/wiki/Cinnamon) bark, and it is garnished with shredded [kaffir lime](/wiki/Kaffir_lime) leaves as well as [coriander](/wiki/Coriander). It is often paired with tomato rice – cooked with tomato sauce or paste, milk, dried spices, and [garlic](/wiki/Garlic), onions and [ginger](/wiki/Ginger). - "Ayam masak merah (Malay-Style Red-Cooked Chicken With Pandan)".
